(1) decrease; (2) decrease
(1) decrease; (2) increase
(1) increases; (2) decrease

variant.question: Wing-tip vortices are formed by the..

options.text: spanwise flow of higher pressure air from beneath the wing outward and upward into the lower pressure air above the wing.
aerodynamic interference of boundary layers from different parts of the aeroplane with those of the wing.
mixing of the high energy airflow over the wing with the free stream air behind the trailing edge of the wing.
rotational velocity imparted to the free stream air resulting from the propeller wash across the top of the wing.

The top to beneath the wing via the leading edge

options.text: Increasing wing tip vortices
Reducing angle of attack
Increasing dynamic pressure

Increase or decrease, depending on the angle of attack
Remain the same.
Increase.

variant.question: Located on the underside of a wing’s leading edge, Vortilons produce a vortex on the wing’s...

options.text: upper surface, at high angles of attack, to reduce the spanwise flow of air.
lower surface, at low angles of attack, to provide improved roll control.
upper surface, at cruise angles of attack, to keep the boundary layer attached to the wing.
lower surface, at high angles of attack, to keep the boundary layer attached to the wing.
